newsitem.title: USA: Strike deadline set at key GM parts plant.
newsitem.headline: Strike deadline set at key GM parts plant.

text.p: The United Auto Workers union tossed another labour grenade at General Motors Corp. Thursday, issuing a strike deadline at a catalytic converter plant in Wisconsin.

A strike at the suburban Milwaukee factory could have a broad impact on GM's global operations. It makes the converters for nearly all of GM's North American-built cars and trucks and also exports to GM's Adam Opel AG unit in Germany.
Shortages of the exhaust system components could quickly force the world's largest automaker to shut down assembly lines.

Dan Dolan, a spokesman for GM's Delphi Energy and Engine Management Systems division, said UAW Local 1866 informed plant management that its 870 members will strike just before midnight on June 12 unless an agreement for a new contract is reached.
"We're working full time trying to reach an agreement without a work stoppage," Dolan said.
Union officials said the issues holding up a new local pact were similar to those that have spawned several GM strikes this year -- outsourcing and manpower.
The union is opposed to plans by GM to buy some of its catalytic converters from outside suppliers and wants GM to replace more retiring workers.

GM is still battling a 44-day-old strike by 5,800 workers at its Pontiac, Mich., truck plant. The automaker recently settled a seven-week walkout at its Oklahoma City car plant by agreeing to hire 325 new workers.
But GM recently informed the Oklahoma workers it would reduce production line speed at the factory, a move that could delay the new hirings promised under the agreement.
